posts.message:
Far-left Nasreen Khan, a shortlisted Labour Party candidate for a Bradford council seat, posted anti-Semitic comments on Facebook and accused teachers of “brainwashing” children into thinking “the bad guy was Hitler”.

And this news breaks on Armistice Day, when we commemorate those who fought that man and his evil and fell for their country of which this creature now seeks to be a legislator?

Whilst my father, who fought in that war and survived, spins in his grave, am I the only person thinking he is now living in a parallel universe?

The woman is an obscenity.

posts.message:
What did my daddy do in WWII? He sacrificed a place at the Royal School of Music to put his age up and enlist at Dartmouth, graduating as an officer with an expertise in navigation and tides.

After the Battle of the Atlantic - during which, as a Lieutenant and the only remaining officer on the bridge under fire, he was mentioned in dispatches and decorated for valour by HM the King for blowing a U-Boat out of the water - he was then, under Churchill's direct orders, transferred to the then top-secret development of Churchill's own brainchild the Mulberry harbour. An observer at the D-Day Landings from a hospital ship - at one point stripping naked to hose down an improvised operating theatre from deck to overhead of blood, guts and gore - he then captained at the rank of Lt Commander, a frigate in the convoys to India where, in Vizagapatam and later Madras - where he obtained a passion for Indian jazz - was part of the planning of the invasion of the Bay of Tokyo.

The bomb having been dropped - which doubtless saved his life - and the Japanese having surrendered, he was then detailed to "independence duties" in Bombay - where he acquired fluent Hindi, a functional facility with Gujarati and a love of the afternoon and evening ragas - and returned to England, I believe, in the Spring of 1948 on a troop ship bearing some of the bedraggled remains of WWII's bravest and best from the Japanese camps and the Burma Campaign who had been too ill to travel earlier, thus witnessing, perhaps, his alternative fate. He never, ever, forgot it.

That's what my daddy did in WWII. What did yours do? Was he one of the dockers on strike at Stalin's behest? Or one of the striking miners in the Welsh pits? Or did yours earn an MBE like Harold Wilson at the Ministry of Ag and Fish eating sandwiches under trying conditions?

That's what my daddy did in WWII. He remained in the service of Queen and country in Navy Intelligence until he finally quit the Reserve after the Prague Spring of 1968.

That's what he did. What did yours do?

An observer at the D-Day Landings from a hospital ship - at one point stripping naked to hose down an improvised operating theatre from deck to overhead of blood, guts and gore - he then captained at the rank of Lt Commander, a frigate in the convoys to India where, in Vizagapatam and later Madras - where he obtained a passion for Indian jazz - was part of the planning of the invasion of the Bay of Tokyo. 

The bomb having been dropped - which doubtless saved his life - and the Japanese having surrendered, he was then detailed to "independence duties" in Bombay - where he acquired fluent Hindi, a functional facility with Gujarati and a love of the afternoon and evening ragas - and returned to England, I believe, in the Spring of 1948 on a troop ship bearing some of the bedraggled remains of WWII's bravest and best from the Japanese camps and the Burma Campaign who had been too ill to travel earlier, thus witnessing, perhaps, his alternative fate. He never, ever, forgot it.

That's what my daddy did in WWII. What did yours do? Was he one of the dockers on strike at Stalin's behest? Or one of the striking miners in the Welsh pits? Or did yours earn an MBE like Harold Wilson at the Ministry of Ag and Fish eating sandwiches under trying conditions?

posts.message: Thanks & respect to your dad,Marplot - a proud record. It strikes a special chord with me because unlike him,I was not robbed of the chance to finish my diplomas with the London College of Music. I did not need to leave my studies to go & fight a war,because selfless people like your dad did the fighting for me many years earlier to enable me to be free.

posts.message: My father arrived home too late to retain his preferential place under the "returned student" scheme and so never completed his musical education. But it was never wasted. He composed a piano concerto - which, my sister, inheriting his musical talent and now a professional musician, once played - and, all his friends marrying and having children, he would compose a lullaby to celebrate each birth, presented to the parents in hand-written and signed partition with a dedication to the baby. It was only upon his death that we discovered he had kept a copy of each and every one of them. They were all of them very pretty little tunes.

posts.message: My father fought in Burma in WW2. So horrific were the scenes he saw there he only ever mentioned the war once to me when I asked him how bad it was, to say he witnessed his friends cut to pieces in front of him by the Japanese and watched them behead some of his regiment. He never spoke of it again but my mother said he was a changed man when he got home, hardened to many situations after that and nothing ever shocked him.

posts.message: When one has lived with brutality and death, then people like the Snowflakes and Millennials of today, live on a different planet and have no idea what terrible sacrifices their forebears and others suffered for them to be free.

posts.message:
I remember my own father would tell a story acceptable to younger children that on the troop ship coming home, there was a man so destroyed by the Japanese cruelty that he could no longer decide what food he wanted to eat. After years of eating gruel and no choice over anything he did, and punished for anything he might have said, given a choice, he would freeze - mentally and physically - stripped of even the human dignity of making a choice. All men, of course, under modern feminism and political correctness, being sub-human and not entitled to choose, this man's fellows with compassionate understanding would try their very best to bring him back to reality, and explain what was on offer. It was the utter degradation of his human condition - to choose - I don't think my father ever forgave and coloured the whole of his political and philosophical outlook. He had had a "good war". Others did not.

To say I am "sorry" for your father's experiences would be self-referential. But I know that I am grateful.
